Text: War is a horror. We must do everything humanly possible to avoid it. https://t.co/CzrkxhE1Fp

You see it over and over. A corporation is greedy, treats its workers poorly. Those workers organize and form a union, the corporation tries to break up that union. And why? Because in a union, it is workers who have the power. And nothing scares corporate America more than that.

Think about this. A diabetic mom in Detroit, Michigan spends upwards of $300 for one vial of insulin.

Just 7 miles away, in Windsor, Ontario, Canada, a diabetic mom pays ONE TENTH of that ‚Äî around $35 ‚Äî for the exact same insulin.

Does that make any sense to you at all?

I get concerned when I hear the familiar drumbeats in Washington demanding we ‚Äòshow strength‚Äô, when we‚Äôre faced with what could be the worst European war in 75 years. We must do all we can to find a diplomatic solution in Ukraine. 
https://t.co/W2jaDl26uG

If Jeff Bezos can afford to dismantle a bridge in Europe so that his $500 million, 417-foot mega-yacht can get to the other side, you know what? Mr. Bezos can afford to pay his fair share of taxes to build a bridge out of poverty for working class families in America. https://t.co/boVynUD9T4

Question. Why is it that in the United States, a diabetic person who paid ~$90 for a vial of Humalog insulin in 2009, must now shell out some $300 for the EXACT same vial of insulin?

Answer. A Congress in Washington, D.C. who lacks the guts to take on Big Pharma's greed.
This is what a corrupt political system looks like. This is why billionaires get richer. This is what Oligarchy is all about. https://t.co/WyKfp3dt2r

True tax rate for the 25 richest people in the United States: 3.4%
Average tax rate for a nurse: 24%

You know what? A nurse should not pay more in income tax than a billionaire. How's that for a radical idea?
I have traveled all over this country. I have never met a single person who has told me they love paying the highest prices on the planet for their prescription drugs.

Cost for one vial of insulin:
üá¶üá∫: $6.94
üá¨üáß: $7.52
üá´üá∑: $9.08
üá©üá™: $11
üá®üá¶: $12
üáØüáµ: $14.40
üá∫üá∏: $98.70

Why should the American people be made to pay, by far, the highest prices on the planet for prescription drugs?

Here is the truth. A tiny handful of incredibly wealthy individuals exercise enormous control over our economic and political system. And what does that mean? Decade after decade, it remains the same: the rich get richer, while the poor and working class get poorer. https://t.co/lz5wjh5b4r

In 2020 alone, the six largest drug companies in the U.S. made nearly $50 BILLION in profits.

The 10 highest-paid pharma executives made over $500 million in total compensation.

Meanwhile, 1 in 4 Americans can't afford the medicines prescribed by their doctor. Unacceptable.

I do not want you to ever grow comfortable with the fact that half our people are living paycheck to paycheck, struggling to keep food on the table, struggling to keep a roof over their heads. That is a moral outrage and it's one we cannot accept.
As you grow old, you should not have to worry about how you're going to afford to keep teeth in your mouth. We must expand Medicare to cover dental care, hearing aids, and eyeglasses.

When you've got 1,500 Big Pharma lobbyists on Capitol Hill for 535 members of Congress, it's not too hard to figure out why prescription drug prices in this country are, on average, 256% HIGHER than in other major countries.
We cannot continue to be the only major country on the planet who does not guarantee a single day of paid leave to new parents.

If you're a pharmaceutical CEO, I'm sure you just L-O-O-O-V-E our health care system ‚Äî best in the world! But if you're someone who needs insulin to survive, you're probably sick & tired of being made to pay 10x what people in Canada pay for insulin. Let's end Big Pharma's greed.
@runforsomething Learn more and sign up: https://t.co/caglY6HUjx

I have run for office many times, and I know, it is not easy stuff. But the only way we are going to win change is if you, and you, and yes, YOU stand up and run for office.

Join me and @runforsomething tomorrow night at 8 PM ET to learn more about running your first campaign. https://t.co/UB0Xf4nxx7

After adjusting for inflation, the average worker in this country is making $49 a week LESS than he or she made 49 years ago. How insane is that?

The time is now to pass an agenda that meets the needs of this country's working class. https://t.co/yRtBE1gTXj
Taking a paid sick day should not be a luxury in the richest country on the face of the planet.

Germany guarantees its people 6 weeks of paid sick leave.
Switzerland guarantees its people 3 weeks.
Australia guarantees its people 10 days.

The United States ‚Äî the richest country on the planet ‚Äî guarantees its people ZERO days of paid sick leave.

Let me ask you a question. Who has the power in America?

Are we content with so few having so much, and exercising so much power when so many people are struggling to get by and have given up on the political process? Or are we prepared to stand up and fight back?

In America today, 745 billionaires now own more wealth than the bottom 60% of all our people combined.

And worse, over the last two years, while those 745 billionaires grew their wealth by some 70%, half our people live paycheck to paycheck.

That's greed. Plain and simple.
In my view, a teacher should not pay more in income tax than the wealthiest person in the country.

At a time when many thousands of essential workers ‚Äî nurses, grocery workers, transportation workers ‚Äî have died as a result of having to go to work during this pandemic, some 740 billionaires in this country have become more than $2 trillion richer. That is morally obscene.

I want you to stop for a moment, and think.

Think about the enormous increase in worker productivity over the last few decades.

And now think about this ‚Äî when accounting for inflation, those workers are making LESS today than they did 49 years ago. Is that acceptable to you?

Since Starbucks workers in Buffalo voted to unionize 2 coffee shops, the movement to organize Starbucks nationally is gaining momentum. Starbucks workers have filed petitions to hold union elections in over 30 coffee shops. We stand in strong solidarity with these workers.

If you think you don't know enough to run for elected office, trust me, I know the U.S. Congress ‚Äî you know enough.

While Kroger workers faced a pay cut in the midst of an ongoing, deadly pandemic, its CEO saw his income skyrocket by some $21 million. That is the kind of ugly corporate greed we are up against, and it's the kind of greed we've got to defeat. https://t.co/plAsag0cvy

If Democrats want to win elections, they should stand up and fight for what the American people want. 

And what they want is pretty clear. https://t.co/AmACSkc4pP

When the richest people in this country are getting richer and richer, no, you as a worker should not accept a deteriorating standard of living. Talk with your fellow workers, get organized, stand up, and fight back.

I know it's not easy, but if ever there was a time in American history that we need to stand up and fight back against the corporate greed we are seeing in this country, this is that moment. https://t.co/zAvyyfXuzW

"The majority of people are demoralized. Programs were put into place to help people with loss, but when you apply for these programs, you face obstruction." - Marthella Johnson, Arkansas Community Organization https://t.co/Tiq7NnXhVw
"You can call Alaska the 'first frontier' of climate change now." - Meda De Witt, Alaskans Take a Stand https://t.co/zxDoc0HUwF

I get so tired of hearing from politicians who tell us they L-O-O-O-O-V-E the country, and yet they apparently do not love the children of our country enough to extend the expanded Child Tax Credit. https://t.co/IgjhypcIgT

I am sitting in Burlington, Vermont, 50 miles north of me is Canada.

Everybody has health care as a human right in Canada. And by the way, they spend about half as much per capita on health care as we do. https://t.co/OgHimLc5jT

HEY. In case you didn't know it, we have the highest rate of childhood poverty of almost major country. 

As a result of the policies in the American Rescue Plan, we have cut childhood poverty by 40% ‚Äî got that? Build Back Better would continue that progress for years to come. https://t.co/9AE1yh8f82

This is the United States. We are the richest country on the planet. One job should be enough to live with security and dignity.

Wage growth from 1979 - 2020:
- For the top 0.1%: wages ‚¨ÜÔ∏è 389%
- For the top 1%: wages ‚¨ÜÔ∏è 179%

Meanwhile, in that same amount of time, wages for the bottom 90% of Americans grew by just 28%. That is not the sort of economic reality we should be comfortable with.
Congratulations to David Ortiz on his well-earned election to the Baseball Hall of Fame. https://t.co/iJhBYUplHw

This is what a rigged economy is all about.

A recent survey found that more than half of the American people could not afford a $1,000 emergency. Meanwhile, the world's 10 richest people have DOUBLED their wealth over the course of the pandemic.

That, to my mind, is absurd.

If we have any chance of restoring hope to the millions of Americans who are living in deprivation and despair, we must act boldly in favor of an agenda that meets the long-neglected needs of the working families of this country.

At a time when half our people are living paycheck to paycheck, NOW is the time to act boldly in the name of an agenda that meets the needs of this country's working class.

Let me congratulate the 8,400 King Soopers workers in Colorado for winning a new contract that includes a pay raise of up to $5 an hour, better healthcare benefits & safer working conditions. This victory proves that when workers stand together they can defeat corporate greed. https://t.co/o6qYhZUJR0

"You're not alone. You're never alone when you're in a union." - Andres Becerril of @UFCW_7 on the power of a union https://t.co/E1ZAbxNpJQ

"When contract time came around, it really hurt a lot of us to see what they really thought of us. Thank god we have a strong union." - Liz Wesley of @UFCW_7 on 'hero pay' being revoked while Kroger's CEO raked in millions https://t.co/xs6e186WwJ

You're not going to hear about this in the corporate media, but if income inequality in this country had remained the same as it was in 1975, the average worker would be making $42,000 more today. That's what a rigged economy is all about.
The essential workers who have kept this country moving have put themselves at great risk during a deadly pandemic. Yes, they deserve to be paid a decent wage and have safe working conditions.

Here's a radical idea: the workers who quite literally keep this country fed should not be paid so poorly that they struggle to put food on their own tables.

Dr. King was a great civil rights leader, but he was more than that.¬†He was a political revolutionary who summoned the nation to ‚Äúundergo a radical revolution of values‚Äù to overcome ‚Äúthe giant triplets of racism, extreme materialism, and militarism.‚Äù Never forget his vision.
Let us not forget where Dr. King was when he was assassinated. He was marching with exploited sanitation workers in Memphis, Tennessee who were underpaid and working under terrible conditions.

I want you to think about this. The life expectancy of wealthy people in this country is roughly 15 years longer than it is for poor people. Got that?

Poverty in America should not be a death sentence.

You know what? If Kroger can afford to pay its CEO over 900x MORE than their median worker, then yeah, they can afford to pay their workers a decent wage, provide decent benefits, and invest in safe working conditions.

When people tell you that the economy is doing very well ‚Äî very well for who? Yeah, the people on top have never had it better. But the reality for working people is that wages for the average worker have barely budged in DECADES.

The Democratic Party has a fundamental question to ask itself.

Are you prepared to stand with struggling working families all over this country? Do you have the guts to take on the moneyed interests whose greed has caused such enormous pain for so many?

Which side are you on?

I stand in solidarity with the 8,400 striking workers at Kroger in Colorado. If Kroger can afford to pay its CEO over $20 million and spend $1 billion on stock buybacks, you know what? It can afford to pay its workers better wages and benefits with safe working conditions.

What is it called when CEOs who are paid millions of dollars say to their workers, 'You know what? You've got it too good. You don't deserve to make a decent wage. You don't deserve decent benefits.'

I call it class warfare, and in solidarity, the working class can win that war.
Congratulations to Starbucks workers who are now organizing union shops across the country in NY, AZ, MA, WA, TN, CO, OR and OH.¬† Good luck!
Every American deserves a high-quality N95 mask to protect themselves from this virus.

Here is the reality for the working class.
Half our people live paycheck to paycheck.
People risk their lives, risk exposure to COVID to go to work.
90 million are uninsured or underinsured.
And because of the power of money, that economic reality is going ignored in Washington.
Not all masks are created equal. https://t.co/eLtBkbfk5c

As a society, we have got to ask ourselves if we are comfortable living in a country where the top 1% own more wealth than the bottom 92%. This is not just an issue of economics ‚Äî this is an issue of our morality.

Not all face masks are created equal.¬†N95 face masks are far more effective than cloth masks in preventing the spread of COVID.¬†We must utilize the Defense¬†Production Act to mass produce these masks and distribute them to every household in the country.

A CEO should not be paid 350x what the average worker at the company is paid.

When we talk about income and wealth inequality in America today, this is what we're talking about.

Right now, the two wealthiest people own more wealth than the bottom 40%. Got that? TWO PEOPLE own more wealth than 40% of our people.

Is that remotely acceptable to you?
